alert.note: Alert for Custer Co Plains; Oglala Lakota (South Dakota) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS RapidCity (Western South Dakota and Northeastern Wyoming)
info.headline: Wind Chill Warning issued December 22 at 10:33AM MST until December 23 at 5:00PM MST by NWS RapidCity
info.description: ...EXTREME COLD AND DANGEROUS WIND CHILLS WILL CONTINUE THROUGH FRIDAY... ...TRAVEL IMPACTS DUE TO BLOWING SNOW THROUGH FRIDAY... .Strong gusty winds will persist across much of the area through early Friday, with the strongest winds expected to continue into this evening. The combination of wind and freshly fallen snowfall from Wednesday will result in blowing snow and blizzard or near blizzard conditions at times across the northwest into west central South Dakota plains. Areas of blowing snow can be expected elsewhere on the plains, with reduced visibilities at times. Dangerously cold wind chills will continue over western South Dakota and northeastern Wyoming through late week. The coldest wind chills are expected this morning through Friday morning, with values of 30 below to near 60 below zero in most areas through Friday morning. ...WIND CHILL WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 5 PM MST FRIDAY... ...WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 5 AM MST FRIDAY... * WHAT...For the Wind Chill Warning, dangerously cold wind chills. Wind chills as low as 50 below zero. For the Winter Weather Advisory, areas of blowing snow. Winds gusting as high as 45 mph. * WHERE...The Custer County Plains and Oglala Lakota County. This includes the Tribal Lands of the Pine Ridge Reservation. * WHEN...For the Wind Chill Warning, until 5 PM MST Friday. For the Winter Weather Advisory, until 5 AM MST Friday. * IMPACTS...Areas of blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility. The dangerously cold wind chills could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as 10 minutes.
info.instruction: A Wind Chill Warning means the combination of wind and cold temperatures will create dangerously low wind chill values. Even if you are outdoors for just a few minutes, cover all parts of your body, especially your head, face, and hands. Use caution while traveling, especially in open areas. Road conditions are available on your smartphone from the 5 1 1 app for your state.
